descriptions.IIoT Edge Platform:
Overview of IIoT Edge Platforms

An Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) edge platform is a technology solution designed to connect, monitor, and manage industrial assets and processes. It brings computational power closer to the data source, enabling real-time data processing and analytics. This minimizes latency, reduces bandwidth usage, and enhances data security.

How IIoT Edge Platforms Help:

  • Real-Time Monitoring: Provides immediate insights into equipment efficiency and process performance.
  • Big Data Management: Facilitates the collection, storage, and analysis of vast amounts of data generated by industrial equipment.
  • Self-Learning Analytics: Uses machine learning algorithms to analyze data and predict maintenance needs, enhancing operational efficiency.
  • Intrusion Detection: Ensures security by monitoring network traffic and detecting potential threats.
  • Centralized Management: Simplifies the management of multiple devices and systems from a single console.
  • Ubiquitous Access: Allows users to access the platform from any device, ensuring flexibility and mobility.

Introducing Datatron by DatatroniQ

Datatron is an advanced IIoT edge platform designed to optimize manufacturing processes through real-time monitoring, big data analytics, and machine learning. It helps manufacturers achieve a smarter, more efficient operation by providing comprehensive tools for data collection, analysis, and management.

Learn more about Datatron

Key Features of Datatron:

  • Real-Time Dashboard:

    Monitors equipment efficiency and measures process performance, offering real-time visibility across all managed assets. Simplifies operational complexity and promotes leaner, more efficient processes.

  • Big Data Platform:

    Uses cutting-edge technology to ensure reliable data pipelines. Makes big data accessible and adoptable for the manufacturing industry, supporting data-driven decision-making.

  • Self-Learning Analytics:

    Automated model building for data analysis. Produces smart actions in a data-driven environment
descriptions.Edge Device Hardware Installation:
Differences Between Large, Medium, and Small Edge Device (Coming Soon)

Large Edge Devices:

  • Capabilities:

    High computational power, extensive storage capacity, and advanced connectivity options. Can handle complex data processing and analytics tasks.

  • Typical Use Cases:

    Large-scale industrial environments, data centers, and facilities with high data volume and processing needs. Suitable for applications like real-time analytics, machine learning, and AI processing.

  • Suitable Environments:

    Factories, large manufacturing plants, smart cities, and other large-scale industrial settings where high performance and reliability are required.

Medium Edge Device (Coming Soon):

  • Capabilities:

    Moderate computational power and storage capacity, suitable for handling intermediate data processing and analytics tasks. Balances performance and cost.

  • Typical Use Cases:

    Medium-sized industrial environments, facilities with moderate data volume and processing needs. Suitable for applications like local data aggregation, moderate real-time processing, and device management.

  • Suitable Environments:

    Mid-sized factories, warehouses, retail environments, and remote industrial sites where a balance of performance and cost is important.

Small Edge Device (Coming Soon):

  • Capabilities:

    Lower computational power and storage capacity, designed for basic data processing tasks. Focus on energy efficiency and compact form factor.

  • Typical Use Cases:

    Small-scale industrial environments, IoT applications, and scenarios with low data volume and simple processing needs. Suitable for applications like simple data collection, basic real-time monitoring, and lightweight edge analytics.

  • Suitable Environments:

    Small factories, individual machines, home automation, and other settings where minimal processing power is required, and energy efficiency is crucial.
descriptions.Central Aggregration Server (Softing Dat:
What is a Central Aggregation Server (Softing dataFEED OPC Suite or legacy: Kepware)?

A Central Aggregation Server collects, processes, and manages data from various sources across an industrial environment. It acts as a hub for data integration, ensuring seamless communication and data flow between different systems and devices.

Key Features of Central Aggregation Servers:

  • Data Integration:

    Collects data from various sources and integrates it into a unified system.

  • Centralized Management:

    Provides a single point of control for managing all connected devices and systems.

  • Scalability:

    Supports large-scale data collection and management from multiple devices.

  • Data Normalization:

    Normalizes data from different sources to a common format for easier analysis.

  • Advanced Analytics:

    Offers advanced analytics capabilities for in-depth data analysis and insights.

  • Historical Data Storage:

    Stores historical data for long-term analysis and reporting.

Learn more about Softing dataFEED OPC Suite

edge_device_hardware_installation.question: I have an edge device and I dont know how to install it next to the PLC. Which edge device do you have?

standard_systems_installed.question: Are you not sure if standard systems are installed?
options: I want to evaluate which standard system might be relevant
I am not sure if standard systems are installed.
I know that we do not have standard systems installed.

strategic_priorities.question: What is the strategic priority of that process and machine in particular for your entity?

plc_hardware_standardization.question: Is the PLC type standardized for this machine type?

plc_software_standardization.question: Has the machine type been standardized not only in hardware but also in software?

other_endpoint_types.question: Are Endpoints such as PLC/HMIs or other Datasources (Sensors, Cameras, Robots. ...) dedicated to this Machine Type?

process_complexity.question: Judge the overal process complexity: Consider the knowledge of the operators / setup personal needed to run / setup the process as a indication.

process_maturity.question: How Mature is the concerned process at this time?

analytics_use_cases.question: Do you think the machine will be subject to future analytical assessments based on time series data from the process?

data_acquisition.question: Does the machine you want to connect contain important high-frequency values such as high dynamic pressure curves e.g. air pressure, hydraulic pressure, some temperature values (e.g. autoclave or brazing / soldering), current, torque, vibrations

rule_engine_transformation.question: Does the machine you want to connect require the raw data to be transformed or shaped before submission to the MSB? e.g. calculations based on raw values to achieve standardized information?

data_buffering.question: Is it critical to buffer data on the machine to overcome network outages or other disruptions in the overal system availability to assure to dont loose data?

local_dashboarding_hmi.question: Does the machine you want to connect require a visualization/dashboard or an HMI directly on the machine?

conditions.expected_answer: I want to order a new machine and I need a Standard Document

I want to order a new machine and I need.description:
Process valid for:


Standard Document:
Check out the Standard Document within Compliance Quest: Electrical Standard - Equipment Integration Extension.
In case you have any specific questions, please use our Q&A funnel (Q&A Funnel) or reach out to us (Email us).

(Optional) Preparation for Discussion
In case you need a fast answer, make sure that you set up a short meeting (max. 30min).
If there are specific questions, be prepared for the following topics:

  • Urgent Needs: Point out the urgent need for clarification regarding the available Standard Document
  • Equipment: Make sure that you have an equipment list (https://ci-shortcode.conti.de/kmk1) with all related details available.
  • (Optional) Use case Benefits and Savings: Make sure that you have a detailed plan for the use cases (https://ci-shortcode.conti.de/mn6m), including calculated benefits and savings.

I know that we do not have standard syst.description:
Rollout Preparation for Standard Systems

In case you do not have standard systems installed, please have a look into the Plant Capabilities & System Availability & Rollout upfront.

In case you cannot find any system for your plant in the list, reach out to MPEE Operations Digitalization (Email us) to discuss your options.

Preparation for Discussion

Be prepared for the following topics:

  • Urgent Needs: Point out the urgent need and use case that needs to be implemented.
  • Equipment and Use Cases: Make sure that you have an equipment list (Please use the Machine List) and a list of use cases (Please use the Use Case List) available.
  • Use case Benefits and Savings: Make sure that you have calculated the benefits and savings for your use cases.
  • Follow Up: In case you need a fast answer, make sure that you set up a short meeting (max. 30min).

IIoT Edge Platform - Siemens S7 Integrat.description:
The Siemens S7 PLC can be connected using the IIoT Edge Platform:

Process valid for:


Budget Planning:

  1. Make sure that budget for the Edge Device + other OT devices (Switches, cabling, etc.) is available
  2. Make sure that budget for IT Infrastructure is available (e.g. software subscriptions, cabling from edge device to OT switch)
  3. For planning purposes use the available budget planning template - If you don't know what that is, reach out to us.

Infrastructure Preconditions:

  1. Make sure that the IT infrastructure (especially cabling) is available
  2. Make sure that power supply for the edge device is available (If necessary: check the datasheet of the used edge device)

PLC / Machine Specific Preparation Tasks:

  1. Provide Machine Details (Interfaces, PLC Types, other endpoints like HMIs etc.) within the Machine List (Machine List)
  2. Make sure that you have a machine specific Integration Plan available (network diagram with endpoints, protocols, connections, etc.)
  3. Make sure that you have the PLC programs of the machine available in an appropriate format (entire PLC program including an S7P file)
  4. In case you do not have the PLC program available, make sure that you reach out to the machine supplier to request the PLC program
  5. In case you do not have the PLC program or you did not request the PLC program / you did not receive the PLC program, we CAN NOT connect the PLC!
  6. Make sure that you have the capability to adjust the PLC program to be able to communicate with the Edge Device (implement function block, adjust hardware configuration, etc.)
  7. Upload the PLC program in the Machine CV (Machine CV)
  8. Export the Tags based on the PLC program using the available Export Tools (Tag Export)
  9. Provide IP address and connection details (PLC related) to connect the PLC to the edge device
  10. Add Edge device details into the available Edge Device List: Edge Device List

IT specific tasks:

  1. Provide IP address for the edge device
  2. Configure the provided IP address on the edge device at ETH1

PLC / Machine specific tasks:

  1. Connect the PLC to the edge device (If you don't know it use the documentation here: Documentation)
  2. Mount the edge device into machine cabinet (24 V power to edge device).
  3. Connect shopfloor ethernet for edge device to central access switch (ETH1 - see also IT specific tasks)
  4. Join edge device into IIoT Edge Server cluster.
  5. Connect the PLC to PROFINET Interface of Edge Device (make sure that you have performed the PLC program adjustments)
  6. Configure Device (PLC) in IIoT Edge Management Dashboard (esp. Endpoint configuration according to OT Cyber Security Rules)
  7. Activate Software Connector via IIoT Edge Management Dashboard
  8. Import the List of selected tags manually (for support semi-automated scripts are available)
  9. Check connection/communication between PLC and edge device.
  10. Check if data is available after enabling the data collection mode
  11. Make sure you change the status of the machine and edge device in the following lists: Machine List (Machine List) and Edge Device List (Edge Device List)

IIoT Edge Platform - Siemens TIA Integra.description:
IIoT Edge Platform - Siemens TIA Integration

Process valid for:


Budget Planning:

  1. Ensure budget for the Edge Device + other OT devices (Switches, cabling, etc.) is available.
  2. Ensure budget for IT Infrastructure is available (e.g., software subscriptions, cabling from edge device to OT switch).
  3. Use available budget planning template for planning purposes.

Infrastructure Preconditions:

  1. Ensure IT infrastructure (especially cabling) is available.
  2. Ensure power supply for the edge device is available (refer to the datasheet of the used edge device).

PLC / Machine Specific Preparation Tasks:

  1. Provide Machine Details (Interfaces, PLC Types, other endpoints like HMIs etc.) within the Machine List (Machine List)
  2. Make sure that you have a machine specific Integration Plan available (network diagram with endpoints, protocols, connections, etc.)
  3. Make sure that you have the PLC programs of the machine available in an appropriate format (entire PLC program including an zapXX-file [XX means the TIA Version])
  4. Upload the PLC program in the Machine CV (Link: Machine CV)
  5. Export the Tags based on the PLC program using the available Export Tools (Tag Export: Tag Export)
  6. Make sure that you have an IP Address for the PLC available
  7. Add Edge device details into the available Edge Device List: Edge Device List

IT specific tasks:

  1. Provide IP address for the edge device
  2. Configure the provided IP address on the edge device at ETH1

PLC / Machine Specific Integration Tasks:

  1. Configure edge device in IIoT Edge Management Dashboard
  2. Mount the edge device into machine cabinet (24 V power to edge device).
  3. Connect shopfloor ethernet for edge device to central access switch (ETH1 - see also IT specific tasks)
  4. Join edge device into IIoT Edge Server cluster.
  5. Connect the PLC to ETH2 of Edge Device.
  6. Configure Device (PLC) in IIoT Edge Management Dashboard (esp. Enable secure communication for PLCs + Endpoint configuration according to OT Cyber Security Rules)
  7. Activate Software Connector via IIoT Edge Management Dashboard
  8. Import the List of selected tags (manually) or Import the List of all PLC tags via inbuild IIoT Edge Management Dashboard functionalities (automatic)
  9. IF automatic approach was chosen - Select your tags (for support semi automated scripts are available)
  10. Check connection/communication between PLC and edge device.
  11. Check if data is available after enabling the data collection mode
  12. Make sure you change the status of the machine and edge device in the following lists: Machine List (Machine List) and Edge Device List (Edge Device List)

IIoT Edge Platform - Sinuvars Integratio.description:
The Siemens NCU Sinuvars can be connected using the IIoT Edge Platform:
  • Task 1: Provide Machine Details inside the Machine List: Machine List
  • Task 2: Make sure that connection details are available (ip adresses, etc.)
  • Task 3: Make sure that the endpoints are connected according to OT Cyber Security Rules: Connext Wiki
  • Task 4: Provide the list of tags that are mandatory and optional to collect from your machine and make it available in the Machine CV: Machine CV
  • Task 5: Inform MPEE Operations Digitalization Team: Email us

IIoT Edge Platform - OPC-UA Server Integ.description:
IIoT Edge Platform - OPC-UA Server Integration

Process valid for:

Budget Planning:

  • Task 1: Ensure budget for the OT devices (connectors [e.g. Helmholz Netlink], switches, cabling, etc.) is available.
  • Task 2: Ensure budget for IT Infrastructure is available (e.g., software subscriptions, cabling from edge device to OT switch).
  • Task 3: Use available budget planning template for planning purposes.
Infrastructure Preconditions:
  • Task 1: Ensure IT infrastructure (especially cabling) is available.
  • Task 2: Ensure OT devices and cabeling is available to connect to the IT infrastructure.
PLC / Machine Specific Preparation Tasks:
  • Task 1: Provide Machine Details inside the Machine List.
  • Task 2: Make sure that your machines are connected to the OPC-UA Server (Softing DataFEED OPC Suite).
  • Task 3: Make sure that connection details are available for the OPC-UA Server Endpoint (IP addresses, credentials, certificates).
  • Task 4: Make sure that the structure on the OPC-UA Server is clear and known (based on your integrated machines).
  • Task 5: Make sure that the IIoT Edge Platform is installed and all Endpoints are known.
  • Task 6: Utilize the following instruction to establish the connection between the OPC-UA Aggregation Server and the IIoT Edge Platform: Instructions
  • Task 7: Make sure that the endpoints are connected according to OT Cyber Security Rules (Connext Wiki).
  • Task 8: Inform MPEE Operations Digitalization Team: Email us

conditions.expected_answer: Central Aggregration Server (Softing DataFeed (or legacy: Kepware))

Central Aggregation Server - Siemens S7.description:
The Siemens S7 PLC can be connected using the Softing DataFeed:

Process valid for:

Budget Planning:

  1. Ensure budget for the OT devices (connectors [e.g. Helmholz Netlink], switches, cabling, etc.) is available.
  2. Ensure budget for IT Infrastructure is available (e.g., software subscriptions, cabling from edge device to OT switch).
  3. Use available budget planning template for planning purposes.

Infrastructure Preconditions:

  1. Ensure IT infrastructure (especially cabling) is available.
  2. Ensure OT devices or PLCs and cabling is available to connect to the IT infrastructure.
  3. Ensure that the OT devices or PLCs have an IP address assigned from IT.

PLC / Machine Specific Preparation Tasks:

  1. Provide Machine Details (Machine Name, IP Address of PLC, communication protocols, plc program, PLC Types, etc.) within the Machine List.
  2. In case you do not have the PLC program available, make sure that you reach out to the machine supplier to request the PLC program.
  3. BREAKPOINT: In case you do not have the PLC program or you did not request the PLC program / you did not receive the PLC program, we CAN NOT connect the PLC!
  4. Make sure that you have the capability to implement OT devices (such as Helmholz Netlink, or else) to be able to connect to the given machine interface.
  5. Make sure that you have the Softing OPC-UA Aggregation Server available. In case it is not available, you CAN NOT connect the PLCs when you have chosen the OPC-UA server as the connectivity framework and you don't have the IIoT Edge Computing Platform available! Go ahead with Task 5 and following or follow the given guideline: Machine Integration - Softing DataFeed - Siemens S7-300 / S7-400 / S7-1200 / S7-1500 Integration.
  6. Once logged in on the Softing OPC-UA Aggregation Server:
    1. Navigate to Data Sources and select Siemens.
    2. Create a new connection.
    3. Define a unique connection name (e.g., PLC Name or Machine Name).
    4. Enable the connection to the PLC.
    5. Select the applicable Siemens protocol to communicate with the PLC (e.g., Siemens S7, Siemens S7-2, Siemens S5, Netlink, etc.).
    6. Configure the given and known IP Address of the PLC for communication. Options include IPV4, IPV6 address, or a hostname.
    7. Configure advanced settings per PLC Communication Protocol, such as Header Definition (e.g., RFC1006 Header), Write Permission (to send values to the PLC), RFC1006 Settings (e.g., Service, Rack, and Slot settings).
    8. Configure Read Optimization to avoid reading complete blocks when single variables are requested.
    9. Define the Cyclic Read time interval (e.g., 1000 ms) for requesting variables from the PLC.
    10. Prioritize Read Requests to prioritize read requests before executing write requests in the queue.
    11. Specify to convert Date Time value to text format.
  7. Use the Connection Test to check the availability of the specified PLC.
  8. Define the available Tags from the PLC in a structured way (e.g., CT Base or other data model integration).
  9. Manual Definition: Define each Tag manually by Name and Syntax (Identifier, e.g., 'DB15,INT1032').
  10. Symbol File Import: Import an exported SDFI file created based on the PLC Program (e.g., S7 project, etc.).
  11. Import Items Wizard: Import a txt file created based on the PLC Program in a defined format (custom Softing data format).

conditions.expected_answer: Central Aggregration Server (Softing DataFeed (or legacy: Kepware))

Central Aggregation Server - Siemens TIA.description:
Machine Integration: Softing DataFeed - Siemens TIA Integration

Process valid for:

Budget Planning:

  1. Ensure budget for the OT devices (connectors [e.g. Helmholz Netlink], switches, cabling, etc.) is available.
  2. Ensure budget for IT Infrastructure is available (e.g., software subscriptions, cabling from edge device to OT switch).
  3. Use available budget planning template for planning purposes.

Infrastructure Preconditions:

  1. Ensure IT infrastructure (especially cabling) is available.
  2. Ensure OT devices or PLCs and cabling is available to connect to the IT infrastructure.
  3. Ensure that the OT devices or PLCs have an IP address assigned from IT.

PLC / Machine Specific Preparation Tasks:

  1. Provide Machine Details (Machine Name, IP Address of PLC, communication protocols, PLC program, PLC Types, etc.) within the Machine List.
  2. In case you do not have the PLC program available, make sure that you reach out to the machine supplier to request the PLC program.
  3. BREAKPOINT: In case you do not have the PLC program or you did not request the PLC program / you did not receive the PLC program, we CAN NOT connect the PLC!
  4. Make sure that you have the capability to implement OT devices (such as Helmholz Netlink, or else) to be able to connect to the given machine interface.
  5. Make sure that you have the Softing OPC-UA Aggregation Server available. In case it is not available, you CAN NOT connect the PLCs when you have chosen the OPC-UA server as the connectivity framework and you don't have the IIoT Edge Computing Platform available!

Go ahead with Task 5 and following or follow the given guideline: Machine Integration - Softing DataFeed - Siemens S7-300 / S7-400 / S7-1200 / S7-1500 Integration

  1. Once logged in on the Softing OPC-UA Aggregation Server:
    1. Navigate to Data Sources and select Siemens.
    2. Create a new connection.
    3. Define a unique connection name (e.g., PLC Name or Machine Name).
    4. Enable the connection to the PLC.
    5. Select the applicable Siemens protocol to communicate with the Siemens TIA (Siemens S7-2: Only for SIMATIC S7-1200 AND S7-1500).
    6. Configure the given and known IP Address of the PLC for communication. Options include IPV4, IPV6 address, or a hostname.
    7. Configure advanced settings per PLC Communication Protocol, such as Header Definition (e.g., RFC1006 Header), Write Permission (to send values to the PLC), RFC1006 Settings (e.g., Service, Rack, and Slot settings)
    8. Configure Read Optimization to avoid reading complete blocks when single variables are requested.
    9. Define the Cyclic Read time interval (e.g., 1000 ms) for requesting variables from the PLC.
    10. Prioritize Read Requests to prioritize read requests before executing write requests in the queue.
    11. Specify to convert Date Time value to text format.
  2. Use the Connection Test to check the availability of the specified PLC.
  3. Define the available Tags from the PLC in a structured way (e.g., CT Base or other data model integration).
  4. Manual Definition: Define each Tag manually by Name and Syntax (Identifier, e.g., 'DB15, INT1032') .
  5. Symbol File Import: Import an exported SDFI file created based on the PLC Program (e.g., S7 project, etc.).
  6. Import Items Wizard: Import a txt file created based on the PLC Program in a defined format (custom Softing data format).

conditions.expected_answer: Central Aggregration Server (Softing DataFeed (or legacy: Kepware))

Central Aggregation Server - Sinuvars In.description:
The Sinuvars Integration can be connected using the Central Aggregation Server:
  • Task 1: Provide Machine Details inside the Machine List: Machine List
    • ]

Central Aggregation Server - Beckhoff In.description:
Beckhoff PLCs can be connected using the Softing dataFEED OPC Suite:

Process valid for:

Budget Planning:

  1. Ensure budget for the OT devices (such as EtherCAT Terminals, switches, cabling) compatible with Beckhoff PLCs is available.
  2. Confirm budget availability for IT infrastructure needs (e.g., network hardware, software licenses).
  3. Employ available budget planning templates to ensure all financial aspects are covered.

Infrastructure Preconditions:

  1. Verify that IT infrastructure, particularly cabling and network devices, is ready and available.
  2. Check the readiness of OT devices or PLCs and their cabling for integration with the IT infrastructure.
  3. Ensure that OT devices or PLCs are assigned an IP address from IT, making them ready for network communication.

PLC / Machine Specific Preparation Tasks:

  1. Collect Machine Details (Machine Name, IP Address of PLC, communication protocols, PLC program, PLC Types) into a centralized Machine List.
  2. If the Beckhoff PLC program is unavailable, initiate contact with the equipment supplier to request the necessary program.
  3. BREAKPOINT: If the PLC program has not been acquired, requested, or received, proceeding with the PLC connection is not possible.
  4. Ensure the implementation capability of OT devices that are compatible with Beckhoff PLCs for connection to specified machines.
  5. Confirm that the Softing OPC-UA Aggregation Server is operational. Without this server, if the OPC-UA server as the connectivity framework and the IIoT Edge Computing Platform are not available, you CAN NOT establish connections to the PLCs. Go ahead with Task 5 and following or follow the given guideline: Machine Integration - Softing dataFEED - Beckhoff PLC Integration.
  6. Once logged in on the Softing OPC-UA Aggregation Server:
    1. Navigate to Data Sources and select Beckhoff.
    2. Set up a new connection.
    3. Define a distinctive connection name (e.g., PLC Name or Machine Name).
    4. Enable the connection to the PLC.
    5. Choose the appropriate Beckhoff protocol (such as ADS) to communicate with the Beckhoff PLCs.
    6. Configure the IP Address of the PLC for communication, including necessary network parameters like port and route settings.
    7. Configure advanced settings specific to Beckhoff Communication Protocol, focusing on ADS port, target and source IDs, and synchronization settings.
    8. Optimize Read Operations to enhance efficiency and reduce network strain.
    9. Determine the Cyclic Read time interval (e.g., 500 ms) to ensure timely data updates from the PLC.
    10. Prioritize Read and Write Requests to manage data traffic and ensure system reliability.
    11. Adjust conversion settings to suit specific data handling and presentation requirements.
  7. Execute a Connection Test to validate the communication link and setup accuracy.
  8. Organize and define Tags from the PLC in a structured manner for effective data handling.
  9. Manually define each Tag by specifying Name and Syntax (e.g., 'GlobalVar.intSpeed').
  10. Import configuration settings or Tag lists from a prepared file that reflects the specific setup of the Beckhoff PLC.
  11. Utilize the Import Items Wizard to upload configurations or parameter settings from a designated file format optimized for the Softing dataFEED OPC Suite.

conditions.expected_answer: Central Aggregration Server (Softing DataFeed (or legacy: Kepware))

Central Aggregation Server - Modbus PLC.description:
Modbus PLCs Integration: Softing dataFEED OPC Suite:

Process valid for:

Budget Planning:

  1. Ensure budget for the OT devices (e.g., Modbus modules, switches, cabling) is available.
  2. Confirm budget for IT infrastructure is available (e.g., software licenses, additional network equipment).
  3. Use available budget planning templates for planning purposes.

Infrastructure Preconditions:

  1. Confirm that IT infrastructure (especially cabling) is sufficiently prepared and available.
  2. Ensure OT devices or PLCs and cabling are ready to connect to the IT infrastructure.
  3. Check that OT devices or PLCs have an IP address assigned from IT.

PLC / Machine Specific Preparation Tasks:

  1. Document Machine Details (Machine Name, IP Address of PLC, communication protocols, PLC program, PLC Types) in the Machine List.
  2. If the PLC program is not available, reach out to the machine supplier to request the necessary PLC program.
  3. BREAKPOINT: If the PLC program is not available, or has not been requested or received, connection to the PLC cannot proceed!
  4. Ensure the capability to implement OT devices compatible with Modbus communication to interface with the specified machines.
  5. Confirm that the Softing OPC-UA Aggregation Server is available. Without this server, and lacking the OPC-UA server framework and the IIoT Edge Computing Platform, you cannot connect the PLCs.

Integration Steps:

  1. Once logged into the Softing OPC-UA Aggregation Server:
    1. Navigate to Data Sources and choose Modbus.
    2. Create a new connection.
    3. Define a unique connection name (e.g., PLC Name or Machine Name).
    4. Enable the connection to the PLC.
    5. Select the applicable Modbus protocol (TCP or RTU) to communicate with the Modbus PLCs.
    6. Configure the given and known IP Address of the PLC for communication. Options include IPV4, IPV6 address, or a hostname.
    7. Configure advanced settings per Modbus Communication Protocol, such as timeout settings, polling intervals, and retries.
    8. Optimize Read Operations to avoid reading complete blocks when single variables are requested.
    9. Define the Cyclic Read time interval (e.g., 1000 ms) for requesting variables from the PLC.
    10. Prioritize Read Requests to prioritize read requests before executing write requests in the queue.
    11. Adjust settings to convert numeric data into required formats (e.g., from raw counts to engineering units).
  2. Use the Connection Test to check the availability of the specified PLC.
  3. Define and organize Tags from the PLC in a structured way for efficient data management.
  4. Manual Definition: Define each Tag manually by specifying Name and Syntax (e.g., 'Holding Register, HR300').
  5. Symbol File Import: Import an exported file created based on the PLC Program.
  6. Import Items Wizard: Import a text file created based on the PLC Program in a defined format (custom Softing data format).

conditions.expected_answer: Central Aggregration Server (Softing DataFeed (or legacy: Kepware))

  • Task 1: Provide Machine Details inside the Machine List: Machine List
  • Task 2: Make sure that connection details are available (ip adresses, credentials, certificates)
  • Task 3: Make sure that the endpoints are connected according to OT Cyber Security Rules: Connext Wiki

  • Task 5: Inform MPEE Operations Digitalization Team: Email us

Integration of Other PLCs.description:
In case you want to connect a PLC that is not available inside the provided list, you must reach out to the MPEE Operations Digitalization Team (Email us). Make sure to be prepared for the following topics:
  • Task 1: Provide Machine Details using the Machine List: Machine List
  • Task 2: Provide PLC Details (Name, Type, Vendor (Contact details), Interfaces, etc.)
  • Task 3: Inform MPEE Operations Digitalization Team: Email us
Depending on your PLC details and the Integration method that you want to use, we need to start the connector development and deployment to integrate the machines.
In addition you need to consider high lead times for OT and IT cyber security approvals.
Make sure that you are mentioning the available use cases (acc. to available process) that are directly dependent on the custom/unknown/legacy PLC Technology.

large_edge_device.description:
The IIoT Edge Device Hardware Integration:
  • Task 1: Mount the edge device into the machine cabinet.
  • Task 2: Supply 24V power to the edge device.
  • Task 3: Connect shopfloor ethernet for the edge device to the central access switch.
  • Task 4: Obtain the IP address for the edge device from the local IT team.
  • Task 5: Configure the IP address for ETH1 on the edge device.
  • Task 6: Set up the edge device in the DATATRONiQ dashboard.
  • Task 7 (Optional for PROFIBUS only): Exchange the PROFINET connector on the edge device with...
  • Task 8: Link the PLC edge device with the PLC (e.g., Siemens S7-300/400) --> Use PROFINET or PROFIBUS, as applicable.
  • Task 9: Incorporate the edge device into the DATATRONiQ server cluster.

medium_edge_device.description: Attention: Right now there is no approved Small Edge Device (Coming Soon) available, please go with the large edge device or with a low frequency data collection method.

small_edge_device.description: Attention: Right now there is no approved Small Edge Device (Coming Soon) available, please go with the large edge device or with a low frequency data collection method.
